comments.commentBody: Nope, he doubled down.

Paul, I keep trying to give you a thumbs up for your comment, but it's not showing...

Enjoy today's match, hopefully it's not a melee.

Cheers!
I have to hand it to Sam Borden, he's not one to back down from controversy.
You did!  It's a bit of a soft shoe, I believe. :)
Chad -- No, they are not Shia. They are Sunni. They arise from the Egyptian Sunnis, not the Iranian Shia.

Thank you! That was very well explained and gives people more context about the schools of thought, art or force. In my opinion, there is plenty of evidence that the artistic aspect has not died. Since the 1990s, we've had many players that display that vein. Romario, Bebeto, Rivaldo, Ronaldo, Ronaldinho, Kaka,, among others. All of those got the Ballon d'Or in Europe and I doubt you can name another soccer environment that has generated the same amount of talent in the last 20 years. So lets not rush to declare Brazilian futebol dead, and rather hope the pendulum will swing back sooner than later.
I hope our guys go out tomorrow and ignore Felipao a bit to show some enjoyment in playing, which has a way of producing beautiful plays!

Exactly - the fact is Brazil doesn't have the dominant attacking talent it used to have.  I mean going back you had Pele - Garrincha - Carlos Alberto.  Brazil still produces loads of talent - the attacking players just aren't as head and shoulders above as they used to be.  Brazil's defensive players are top notch -which is a reversal.  What does it say that the best attacking player apart from Neymar - Diego Costa - chose to play for Spain.  Strange times.
Let's see.  Ronaldo, Ronaldinho, Rivaldo, Cafu, Roberto Carlos, and Kaka all played together on the national team.  This is one or two "artists"?

Excellent points by Marc and TDK.

To someone raised in a soccer culture, American football looks like a board game played with live pins trying to reenact First WW trench warfare.

Soccer, on the other hand, is all about movement, even guerrilla tactics. Quick vision, finding open spaces, changing pace and moving fast is essential.

You have a broad strategy and some set pieces to begin with. But once the referee gets the game going, the players have to read the game changes and react accordingly all by themselves.

No stopping every 45 seconds to review tactics and reach for the playbook. Tactical acumen and quickfire thinking in the highest degree are required.

Moreover, endurance is more important than height and muscles. And ball skills are paramount (just look at Messi and Neymar).

Ice hockey is closer to soccer. I like to watch it in cable TV, the trouble for an old man with bad sight is keeping track of the puck.

No MLS franchise could come close to buying real talent on the international level. Not talent in their prime, anyway... maybe an over-the-hill star with some name recognition.

Messi and Ronaldo make 7 times what Dempsey ( the highest paid domestic player ) is paid. Almost everyone who actually plays for Barcelona makes more than Dempsey, and Barcelona is only about 5th in payroll.

One more fine article from mr. Vecsey.

As you can imagine, there is a lot of folk wisdom around soccer in Brazil. An old-time coach, Gentil Cardoso, is the source of some of it, and two of his commandments go well with this article:

"if a kid wants to master the ball, he should live with it, go to bed with the ball".

"One must go for the ball as a hungry man going for a plate of food".

'Argentina is about Messi only'...
ALL GREAT PLAYERS COMBINED, ROBBEN AND CR7 INCLUDED do not add up to the brain Messi has inside a field. His brains sees what others don't, he is the gifted among gifted. E PLURIBUS UNUM.
If the Dutch want to win this game, they will have to score first otherwise they will be packing home.
Di Maria is ruled out for the cup.
@WordGuru,  "Messi's brain" has always been Iniesta/Xavi.  And now with Di Maria gone, I don't see much hope for Argentina.

The Dutch have Sneijder, Robben, Kuyt & if he wakes up again - van Persie.
As a fan you notice them & remember them for their contributions & teamwork on the field & tv screen. Argentina is about Messi & whoever he passes the ball to. That was good enough to beat Belgium but not the Dutch.
At any rate, my question to the Netherlands:
If not now, when?
Just win baby.

Seems to me that the only difference between the fouls against Neymar and the fouls against James is that Neymar got hurt. Paulinho didn't receive any cards for fouling James after the play. Rewatching the impact, the foul didn't not seem severe enough to fracture his vertebrae. I agree with a previous comment. His injury is a little suspicious.

On Sunday it was the neocons,
Tuesday brings the bankers.
We are not surly enough for Mr Paul,
Hillary in a landslide.

If Ms. Clinton wants to win primaries she should frame all her economic policies through the lens of "rebuilding American business from the bottom up", i.e. a trickle up approach that genuinely supports small to medium size businesses. This support would include "shock proofing" smaller businesses against the excesses of large corporate mistakes and boondoggles. One big help would be enshrining in law a small business loan insurance program that automatically kicks in to make the payments on small to medium business loans when the economy reaches a threshold depth of recession,

If she wants to win the general election she should then reframe the message to emphasize the increasing economic stability and wealth these policies will bring to Wall Street and its large financial institutions. As this increasing wealth is realized this current anti-Wall Street political pressure can be negotiated to more logically encourage “repatriated” overseas American corporate income; change government backing of home mortgages in ways that better fit the realities of global e-financial system; not totally eliminate the “carried interest” loophole for private equity managers; and more reasonably regulate commodities trading.

Our leaders need to call for both sides to warn their citizens against the rioting, violence, and calls for vengeance. And for the PA to assist in finding the murderers of the three boys; loud and clear. Resuming "peace" talks, or even mentioning them, is way off the mark for now.
Did you wish a pox on the 4 murdered?

That is the consequence of arrogance and illogical thinking. It provides the Israelis with a reason for repeated air strikes on Gaza.

Have Gazans ever considered that ending the rocket fire and agreeing to negotiate with their adversaries will improve their quality of life. Futility consists of repeating the same failed actions and expecting a different result.

A pox on all of them.  Thank heavens this editorial did not presume to concern itself with what our own country should or shouldn't do relative to this ongoing madness.  A tip of the hat to Hamas, however, for continuing to fire rockets at Sderot, thus ensuring that at least a dozen Arabs will die every time they destroy an Israeli lawn.  An insurgency of such astounding incompetence will never be a real threat to a nuclear-armed Israel and will never on its own bring an independent state into being.  The Palestinians deserve far better but, hey, they voted for these people...
What are the odds she's going to propose that again, though?  This article pretty much spells out that Wall Street isn't going to pony up any campaign cash if she proposes any taxes on Wall Street.
I was with you until you got to that farcical comment about light-weight Ted Cruz.

Thank you for your interest in dealing with the greenhouse gas emissions.  When we looked at the problem, we saw a need to  come up with a global system for generating  cheap electric power.  Space solar power can be done & serve the planet 24 hours a day.  We propose creating an international effort funded by international formula similar to the International Monetary Fund.  We can't put this in place overnight but we know that such a system is feasible & all we need is a very low cost payload $/lb launch system & the Maglev Launch system qualifies.  China and Japan are working on the launch system.   It is not a big deal.  It is simply an elevated vacuum pipe that allows Maglev to propel the payload at fantastic speeds by riding the AC wave until it leaves the tube.  There are thermal problems, even at very high altitudes but we believe we have those conquered.  The satellites have been designed and the microwave transmission has been tested.  We don't want to detract from solar and wind, in fact I am all for solar roof tops, but the problem is the sun doesn't always shine and there are many days that clouds prevent full efficiency.  There may be breakthroughs in Thorium power, which would also work but I think this century the entire planet should make an effort to curtail global warming gasses.  The US could use this challenge to create more jobs.  We are coming along with electric transport but the real issue is highway freight trucks, the Maglev network project target.
Well said, Dr. Bob.

Should Jewish life have more value because they are fewer in number than Muslims?! Somehow I don't see that making its way into any declaration of human rights. Dismissing statistics as video games is simply an attempt to ignore evidence. The IDF has killed far more than Hamas or suicide bombers (source: http://ifamericansknew.org/) and much in the same manner - shrapnel in flesh in both. The dead don't care if they were supposed targets or collateral damage. Results and outcomes matter more than alleged "intent". I can't kill 10 people in a crowd and tell a judge I was only trying to kill this one person who I felt threatened by or wanted to exact revenge on - and expect not to be put away for life for 10+1 murders. Why should we judge Israel and the IDF, or Hamas, or anyone else differently?

Dr. Bob, add up all the deaths and the injuries (separately) from any date you wish. Use Wikipedia. The violence Israel has wreaked on Arabs and vice versa. The numbers are very topsy turvy. If all human life has the same value, Israel has been a bigger offender and aggressor than Arabs have been. The truth is that the numbers don't support your narrative, so it's best to avoid them. Here are a few stats that can't be spun by however many allies Israel has in our political and media circles: http://ifamericansknew.org/ and most are from B'Tselem, the respected Israeli human rights body.

The Israeli govt and IDF has no moral standing, except for exceptions like hunting down Khdeir's killers. The Gaza war, and other bombardment campaigns are indistinguishable from what suicide bombers do - I can't absolve myself of the deaths that happen if I pull the trigger on them, by just calling them collateral damage. I can't kill 10 people in a crowd and tell a judge I was only trying to kill this one person who I felt threatened by or wanted to exact revenge on - and expect not to be put away for life for 10+1 murders. Why should we judge Israel and the IDF, or Hamas, or anyone else differently for that matter? Our criminal justice system is moral at its core. And those principles DO translate.

Here is a running count of Israeli and Palestinian children killed since 2000, for those interested in numbers:

http://rememberthesechildren.org/remember2014.html

It appears the courts are saying that if you have a paper-thin claim not to know who benefited from the illegal tip, go ahead and profit from it at the expense of the law abiding.

A good example of how the law protects the worst of the 1%--those who create nothing, but simply game the corrupt system.

Short-term rates are maxed at 39.6%.
Long-term rates are zero, 15, 20% depending on your
ordinary tax rate. An ordinary rate less than 15% may
qualify for the ZERO long-term rate, and a higher than
15% long-term rate would govern whether the 15 or 20%
rate applies.
You don't adore the Clintons and Al Gore?
The situation is a repetition of the ubiquitous behavior of powers-that-be who take the money and escape the blame.

Why is everyone considered an illegal by some of the commenters here? What about sending money for students studying abroad? What about aid workers? Missionaries? Sending money to your elderly grandmother in Croatia?

Many Americans travel or live abroad for many reasons. Many Americans are first or second generation legal immigrants with family responsibilities. Some Americans simply met someone from another country and got married. Does moving with your wife to Toronto make you a bad American? Does sending money to your husband's parents in Italy for their 40th anniversary make you a destroyer of the economy?

What about the American engineers and construction workers who have come to New Zealand to help with the earthquake rebuild? Should they not be able to transfer money to accounts here?

Stop being parochial. We live in a global economy.

Making it harder for people here illegally is a good thing.

But, like everything else, it's the ones gaming the system who make it worse for those doing things in accordance to the way they were designed to be implemented.

I hope people aren't so obtuse to not be able to differentiate between my two statements.

No need for immigrants to be squeezed. Bitcoin is ideally suited for such money transfers, and the cost is less than any funds transfer through the banksters. I'm sure the switch to the Bit has already begun among immigrants and will spread rapidly.

the  crack  down  on  all  the  illegal  money  being  laundered  in  international  banking  has  certainly  taken  its  toll  on  the  banking  system,  criminal's  have  even  turned  to  Bit  Coin,  banks  now  have  very  good  reason  to  name  their  ticket  on  the  fee's
The US government still sends social security checks to other countries and most keep US bank accounts and have debit cards.
